discussion.content: Should be D. You need to enable the SharePoint Server Publishing Infrastructure feature on a site collection level.

Answer D, even in the article on the link it's written:
You enable the SharePoint Server Publishing Infrastructure feature on the site collection level.
D should be the correct answer regardless if it just a single site.

Before you enable managed navigation, make sure that:

You enable the SharePoint Server Publishing Infrastructure feature on the site collection level.
https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/enable-managed-navigation-for-a-site-in-sharepoint-49a067dc-77d2-455d-9e77-250ec7cc0a6d?ui=en-us&rs=en-us&ad=us

Not sure of the right one. Actually both C and D are required. SharePoint Server Publishing depends on Publishing infrastructure. Tested that if you don't enable Server Publishing at Site level, Managed Navigation is not shown.

choices.D: From Site Collection Features, activate SharePoint Server Publishing Infrastructure.
choices.B: From Site Collection Features, activate SharePoint Server Enterprise Site Collection features.
choices.C: From Site Features, activate SharePoint Server Publishing.
choices.A: From Site Features, activate SharePoint Server Enterprise Site features.

questions.question_text:
You have a SharePoint Server farm that has one web application. The web application contains one site collection. The site collection contains one site.
You need to enable managed navigation.
What should you do?

You create a new color palette and font schemes.
You need to use the new palette and schemes to customize your SharePoint Server environment.
Where should you add the files you created?

You have a SharePoint Server 2019 farm. The farm contains several Microsoft Office documents. All the documents have a property named Division that is populated automatically based on the document's author.
You create a text managed property that is retrievable and queryable, and you map the managed property to the Division property.
You need to find only the documents that have the Division property set to Legal.
For what should you search?

discussion.content:
In the exam the answers were a little diferent.
 division and divison!!!!!


A. Division=Legal
B. "Legal"
C. Divison:Legal
D. Legal ONLY

So A is the correct!

= operator is the same as : operator.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/keyword-queries-and-search-conditions?view=o365-worldwide
Do you think the answer should be C Site Columns, managed properties are search based not document check in based
In real life I would implement a site content type.

I'll go for A
Not all crawled content or metadata is useful to have in the search index, so the search schema has a list of useful types of content and metadata, called managed properties.
These managed properties can contain information in integer, decimal, date and time, double precision float, or binary format. 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sharepoint/manage-search-schema
I would prefer answer B. Site content types. Because site content types can have multiple site columns.
Would also go for answer C, site columns.

questions.question_text:
You have a SharePoint Server farm.
You have the following three types of document libraries: expense reports, purchase orders, and invoices. Each document in the libraries has an associated project code and cost center.
You need to ensure that when users check in expense reports, purchase orders, and invoices, the documents are associated to a project code and a cost center.
The project code and cost center must be in a consistent format across all the document libraries. The solution must minimize administrative effort.
What should you include in the solution?

choices.D: This service application is the default storage location for Keywords.
choices.B: Push-down Content Type Publishing updates from the Content Type Gallery to sub-sites and lists using the content type.
choices.A: This service application is the default storage location for column specific term sets.
choices.C: Consumes content types from the Content Type Gallery.

questions.question_text:
You have a SharePoint Server farm.
You plan to use a Managed Metadata Service application.
You need to disable folksonomy.
Which option should you disable from the Managed Metadata Service Connection properties?
